editorial_summary.overview: Modern museum resembling a glass cube & hosting numerous temporary art exhibitions.

reviews.text: The museum is as good as always. Love it when there is a new exhibition. The Ai one was definitely freaky and entertaining. You can always visit tho for the main gallery when there isn’t a special exhibition. You gan give your backpack and jackets to the wardrobe for free.
Not a big fan of modern arts, however I enjoyed a lot of parts in the Museum.
Very boring, definitely not worth the 11€ for the ticket. Most of the "art" is modern, so don't expect to make sense of it. Skip this one

Very interesting and inspiring exhibition in Kunstmuseum! The location is right near by the Schlossplatz. The ticket is around ~20€ per person but there are discounts for some group of people, for example, students. Not very crowed. Much visit place in Stuttgart!

Loved the fact that inside the museum you can see both old and new art pieces, different art currents, different views. And now, with this pandemic going on, they are really prepared for everybody to be safe!

editorial_summary.overview: Permanent & temporary exhibitions of art and artifacts from around the world, plus regular events.

reviews.text: It's a cultural museum concentrating on Tamil culture and traditions. Audio guides were provided. But having a translator is recommended if you don't read German. Google translate would work. Must visit. Fee was 12€ per person.

What a snooze fest other than trying to figure out the jacked up layout; it’s not set up well at all. Maybe it’s just not my forte but I didn’t like it at all and found it was a waste of euro. I wish I could go back and not pay for not only the ‘special’ exhibit but also the regular one. They must know their exhibits aren’t that good because they weren’t as attentively monitoring guests as with the other museums I visited. As a matter of fact they even said that some of their stuff is recreations again another reason the others were better. It takes away the history part of it. Take the mock-up they made below to show the only four jewels they had.

Best place when it us rainy. I visit it with my 8 and 5 years old grand-child. The 8 years old boy loves the audio guide. A great thing. Attention he or she will that u listen whole day 🤟🏾👍🏾😎😋 the little 5 year ild girls loves the Museum too. The People are very friendly. And they participate at the Arabic Film Festival 👍🏾 congrats.

A big museum with many rooms for different kinds of exhibitions. Some exhibitions are paid and some are free. I had the chance to visit a nice one for free and it was amazing. It was enough to get a taste of it. If I had the time, I wouldn't hesitate to visit the rest of them.
Amazing! History, Dialect philosophy etc

Landesmuseum W\u00fcrttemberg.adr_address: Altes Schloss, Schillerpl. 6, 70173 Stuttgart, Germany

editorial_summary.overview: 16th-century palace & cultural museum tracing Swabia's history from the Stone Age to the present.

Landesmuseum W\u00fcrttemberg.name: History Museum Württemberg

reviews.text: Rich and comprehensive. Easily can spend half a day or even more here and the cafe at the hall is just lovely.

No bags allowed, no matter how small. There are lockers with basic locks (I bet the same key would open at least 3 different lockers), no liability. They don't warn about this when selling tickets online, but are adamant about this rule. At least they didn't make a fuss when processing a refund. Will probably try to come later, but one star for now.

Well worth your visit. Check out the floor plan before you go in. There might be some exhibits that come later that you may want to spend more time in. As you walk through everything is in chronological order. I enjoyed the neanderthal, Celts and Roman exhibits the most.

Good place to visit when you’re in Stuttgart. It is exactly adjacent to To the bus station, so you can easily open and half of if you are using public transport. The overall architecture of this place is very good. Love the place, definitely recommend it to anyone who is visiting Stuttgart for first time.

This museum is by my favorite one so far in Stuttgart. The he collection is AMAZING! The rich history, stories and the way it’s set up makes it a total delight. If you go to no other museum here you must go to this one!
Such a fun place to take kids! It was a little busy but it was plenty of blocks to use to build. The bathrooms were clean too!

We went for a kids festival dedicated to constructions! The kids were very happy as they can build their first little house out of foam blocks. They didn't want to leave after 2 hours there. It's open everyday (Mondays as every museum is closed) until 26 Nov, 11:00-18:00.
Great city Museum full of local history to know why Stuttgart is so special

Love this museum. There’s always something interesting going on. We went during Lange Nacht der Museen, and they had a fun exhibition which you could make and record sounds using everyday things. Great place to hang!
Big building filled with Lots of nothing. Only two exhibitions and only one was worth seeing.

editorial_summary.overview: Museum tracing history of Mercedes & the car industry, with vintage & modern vehicles on display.

reviews.text: The MERCEDES-BENZ MUSEUM was amazing! When you first arrive, you take the elevator to the top floor and walk down the spiralling path. It starts with the earliest vehicles and the vehicles get progressively newer the further down you go. The museum was well laid out with plenty of lighting. The parking garage on the backside of the museum made the visit painless and easy.

The museum layout is a bit confusing and the audio guide that they gave me didn’t work. I wish they provided maps for us. When I returned my broken audio guide to the lady, she didn’t seem to care. But overall, it’s a really cool place to visit, especially if you love cars. It’s cool to learn the history of the company. They have tons of vehicles to look at too. If you want to read about everything in the museum a visit will take you an entire day. Definitely worth a trip!! The tickets were well priced and included a free audio guide!

This was my first visit to the Mercedes Museum and I have to admit that I was really positively surprised.
The architecture is amazing and totally fitting to the themes that are shown.
Each of the eight levels tells unique stories throughout the history of Mercedes Benz.
It’s easy to navigate through the museum and just beautifully made.
Worth a visit! Or another one.

Great to see the evolution of cars. Impressive collection of cars from the original to the latest high tech. It's also fun to learn MB makes all kinda of vehicles besides cars.
Family tickets cost 24€ compare to Porsche musume gives you discount when you take public transportation (10€ for 2+2 family).

Mercedes-Benz Museum is another famous and unique attraction at Stuttgart. You can take the train or bus number 45 (better option) from the city centre. The decoration, art quality and exhibits in the museum is world-class and excellent. You will definitely feel shocked and amazing. Apart from different models of benz cars, I admire the introduction of German and even world-wide history. You can learn more practical knowledge and deeper recognition of the growth of this great enterprise. Highly recommended!
Really enjoyed the experience. There are several illusions and puzzles to keep you engage for an hour. Really hope they include more illusions and puzzles.
Incredible experience at a slightly expensive price tag. But worth visiting this place at least once

Nice museum with some very cool illusions.  The biggest complaint is that it's much too small.  There are more elaborate places like this in other cities.  I think it could be twice as big and could use at least another floor.

Loved the experience. Had a fun evening. The illusions are very interesting. Great place to spend an evening.
The place was a bit crowded. We booked the tickets online. But nevertheless since the place is quite small it got pretty crowded. So one has to wait in line at every illusion to take a picture.
So much fun for me and my daughter. I am super happy we went. The museum is not big and each station is explained in both German and English. We had a blast and I fully recommend it to everyone.

editorial_summary.overview: Permanent display of 20th-century art plus special exhibitions of prints, drawings & photographs.

reviews.text: This museum is a lot of fun. The collection is interesting. I like how you can look down through the rooms to the end of the exhibits. Check out the artwork that captured my attention.
Best place to spend time! Lots of modern art and classical arts. There are some special collections every now and then! And its also FREE if you are in student status.
A great art museum right near Stadtmitte.  From Matisse to Picasso, they had a great selection of the masters.

I loved it. It has masterpieces inside like Jackson Pollock,Picasso, Paul Klee, Edvand Munk,Salvador Dali and more ,plus they have an amazing piece of art The cleaning lady by  Duane Hanson 1972 that was incredibly realistic and I thought that a lady was sitting in the middle of the gallery room.
Went for George grosz Ausstellung stayed for other art pieces for quite a long while. Wasn’t prepared for staying so long but we did and enjoyed every single minute of it. 🤓👍🏻

editorial_summary.overview: Dinosaur & fossil displays, plus a prehistoric human skull exhibited in the natural history museum.

Naturkundemuseum am L\u00f6wentor.name: State Museum of Natural History Stuttgart

reviews.text: This is a great place to visit with kids, since it has just enough info and exhibitions to keep them interested. I do think that it has seen better days and it feels as though the exhibitions haven't been properly taken care off. Some exhibitions seem worn by time, at other exhibitions you can find dust. Also, would be nice to have explanations printed out in English as well.

Dinosaurs lovers this is the place to come to, what an amazing collection of everything dinosaurs spread over 3 floors, the attention to detail is amazing, the kids will love and so will us adults as we look back on millions of years before over time
We love this museum. A lot of different spots and activities for kids as well as interesting for adults. Definitely recommend.
Very Entertaining for Kids … I advice you to reserve a tour on the day you go , it’s full of information
Nice place for kids to know about dinosaur mammals nd fishes

editorial_summary.overview: Futuristic museum tracing Porsche's history, with vehicles from early 20th century to the present.

reviews.text:
This is the best experience I ever had in my business trips.

From the moment you are inside of the build you start to feel all the good atmosphere created by all the personal working there.

The system used to guide you through all the museum is available in many languages making really enjoyable being there.

Car you only saw in book or in movies, you have now the opportunity to see them face to face, Amazon experience.

I really loved been there, thank you so much!

Excellent history of Porsche and lots of cool cars. Our whole family including boys (13, 19, and 20) loved it! Well laid out. A great mix of interactive vs historical. Really cool building design. Exceeded expectations!

We went to the Porsche Museum after our visit to the Mercedes-Benz Museum, we had a much better experience here. We arrived by train, so they give you a 50% discount on tickets if you come by train! We only paid 10€ to get in. We we’re provided with a free audio guide, which worked well and had good sound quality. The museum is well laid out and beautiful on the inside. We loved learning the history of Porsche and seeing all their cars from then until now. Definitely worth a visit when in Stuttgart!

I recently had the pleasure of visiting the Porsche Museum in Stuttgart, and I must say it was an experience that exceeded all my expectations. From the moment I stepped through the doors, I was immersed in a world of automotive excellence and rich history.

The museum itself is a stunning architectural masterpiece, blending modern design with elements of the brand's iconic identity. I felt an immediate sense of awe as I gazed upon the impressive collection of meticulously restored classic cars, prototypes, and racing legends on display.  Each car was presented in a way that allowed me to truly appreciate the craftsmanship and artistry behind these remarkable machines. The knowledgeable staff members were also readily available to provide fascinating insights and answer any questions I had, further enhancing my understanding and appreciation of the brand's legacy.

The museum also provided glimpses into the future of Porsche, showcasing cutting-edge concept cars and giving me a glimpse into the brand's commitment to innovation and sustainability. It was inspiring to see how Porsche continues to push boundaries and redefine what is possible in the automotive industry.

In conclusion, my visit to the Porsche Museum in Stuttgart was an unforgettable journey through the rich history and exciting future of one of the world's most renowned automotive brands. Whether you're a Porsche enthusiast or simply appreciate engineering excellence, I highly recommend a visit to this museum. It is a true celebration of automotive artistry and a testament to the remarkable legacy of Porsche

Porsche Museum is one of the must-go attractions in Stuttgart. Apart from the high popularity and prestige status of this famous brand, you can also learn German's high quality in art, design, manufacturing and technology. You can find both the old and new models inside this museum. Besides, you can also visit their cafe and purchase souvenirs in the gift shop. The transportation is very convenient as it is just next to the train station. Highly recommended!

editorial_summary.overview: Modern building with interactive exhibitions explaining more than 2 centuries of regional history.

reviews.text: Second favorite museum here in Stuttgart. Has a little bit of something for everyone; even an old version of the knock down drag out game of Monopoly. What y’all don’t get that serious about Monopoly?  Sorry about the little tangent; I had flashbacks. Though it’s my second favorite I would definitely go back.
The exhibit is not tourist friendly. There's very little context that links the different rooms of the museum. I had very different expectations based on the description

I'd love to say it was great but tge museum is not a good place for someone who has no German knowledge. Everything was in German so we only had to look at the pieces without receiving any information.

Moderately interesting museum showcasing the history of the Baden-Würtemmberg area. Some of the exhibits don't seem to tie together very well and/or feel irrelevant. Additionally, some of the items feel repetitive. For example, there will be a passport from some random soldier from 1939, and then 4 display cases you will find another passport from the same time period. Note these are not significant people, just random documents they've received.
Also note that all item descriptions are in German.

It was very interesting. I did the guided tour which was very good. You learn about the history of the migrants who came to Germany or left Germany. All the stories are true and they are so interesting. You can also see some things these people had with them when they arrived in or left Germany. These people actually told members of staff their story, so it isn't made up either.

editorial_summary.overview: Museum branch covering evolution, tropical rainforests & marine mammals in an 1820s palace.

reviews.text:
Very nice, small so its doesn’t require a lot of walking. Excellent replication of animals from all around.

Most things are mainly in German, so you will find only around 30% in English but it was just good enough.

Very friendly place, and warm inside.
Beautiful described museum. Much information about different varieties of animals, birds etc. All age groups can enjoy there. A very good way to spend the time.

Adult: 5€
Kids: 3€
2023

All exhibitions are is one floor.
Very didactic museum.
There is an astonishing park around the museum.
It's not very big, but it's interesting. They have a life-sized whale, elephant, bear, and many other animals. It was worth the experience with my son.

Really good place to bring your kids or on a first date. Would definitely recommend this place.  Description is even in English.  Only thing that is not easy is to find a good place to park your car, there is the Wilhelma parking space.  Prices are 5 euro for adults and 12 for a year card.

editorial_summary.overview: Hands-on children's museum playfully teaching regional history, arts & culture in a castle setting.

reviews.text:
I definitely recommend it as a day-trip activity for children kindergarten age and up. We visited the fashion exhibition which promised a hands-on experience introducing children to clothes and fabric. We were not disappointed.

The team guiding the children were well prepared and real professionals in how to tailor the presented material to the age of the audience. Our 4-year old child was impressed and children much older than her also seemed to be having a good time.  It was fully interactive but also educational, with children learning about such topics as materials, care instructions, and creating their own patterns. The museum  itself is not very large but the allocated 90 minute window passes by really quickly and you will wish that you could stay for longer.

Recommendation to visit their website regularly and keep track of the different exhibitions that they will put up.

Location/transport: It is slap bang in the centre of Stuttgart so consider public transport or one of the many Parkhouses in the city.
the helpers there were very kind indeed, but  der Räuber Hotzenplotz exhibition was way better than the Fashion for the children.

The pictures above are not current. We bought tickets online and we're the only ones there. No tests required. (Yay!) I went with a three and five year old. It is fashioned after a fashion theme. Coloring and designing with colored pencils. Costumes to try on (not open during corona), a stamping room (three year old liked this) and a studio room with lots of big soft blocks to move was a hit with both kids. You can also make friendship bracelets. Warm inside during summer. Any young children (8-9) interested in fashion may like this stop.

The Children's Museum is a good way to kill an hour or so with kids. The staff inside the museum was super helpful and spoke both German & English. Signage in the museum is also in both languages. There was a lot of interactive stations for kids to learn through hands-on activities. Due to COVID-19, some of the displays were closed or roped off. Looking at other's photos on reviews, it seems that the museum changes themes ever so often. There were a bunch of birthday groups there and my kids didn't feel left out as the staff gave them undivided attention to make sure they were included and tried everything available to them.
Small area but super friendly staff. We spend around 1:30h there and kids had some fun.

editorial_summary.overview: Quirky museum in an old slaughterhouse focused on the history, mythology & gastronomy of pigs.

reviews.text: Wierd collection of pig parafernalia. It is also informative with some pig related data. But it is mostly random weird stuff. I would not say it is a must-visit of Stuttgart but you definitely won't find a similar museum in other places.

Interesting and unexpected. I really liked the miniatures in the museum and the fact that it is really genuine, but could have been a bit "refreshed" from its old appearance, taking into consideration the entrance ticket that is not really cheap. Would have liked to buy a small souvenir but the lady that was taking care of the museum shop didn't even ask me if I wanted something else, just told me that "this is an old museum and paying is possible just by cash" ... Well a bit of upgrading would not be bad, I think! Otherwise, the collection of exponates was really cute :)

Arrived just after 16:00 and everything locked up. When the door opened to let previous visitors out the unfriendly staff insisted they were already closed despite the sign in the door saying last entry 16:15

One of the weirdest places in Stuttgart but it made me so happy to visit. This 40.000 item collection has put the Pig Museum in the Guinness Book of Records. Definitely give this place a try if visiting Stuttgart, Germany.
Visit once, different experience. Restaurant is too good.
There is a nostalgic tram tour to the TV tower. It took 1.30 hours. 20 minutes wait at the TV tower and come back to the museum.

Great place for kids and train lovers. You can see the old Stuttgart street cars in all their glory. There are also several interactive displays and stories detailing the history of the trams. You can also take a ride in the old 23 street car, check on the website for timings and stops. Worth spending a pleasant few hours here on a quiet day.
Great transport museum; strongly recommend to visit on a Sunday and enjoy a heritage tram ride.
Awesome place to visit!

Very cool little museum with trams running on the historic line(s) on a Sunday. Entry fee is reasonable and you can get a combo ticket for the tram rides and museum entry. I understand they are going through some renovations at the moment and that one of the historic lines is not operational (I would recommend looking in advance on their website), but what they have on display is so amazingly well kept by the dedicated staff who volunteer here. Seriously, a big kudos to everyone who keeps these vehicles in tip top shape! You can buy books and models in the front of the museum; SSB models were available for purchase when I was there.
Super Museum.
Tip!

We went there with a group for a guided tour. It's a really great museum where you can see how much heart and soul was put into it. Mr. Stolz led us through the museum, you can see immediately how much fun he had for years in his job as a police officer. The tour lasted two hours, we probably could have stayed in the museum for a few more hours without getting bored.
A visit is definitely worth it 😃
The tour started on time, there were enough parking spaces (Saturday). Great tour, very loving showcases. An interesting and very entertaining visit to the museum!

Consistently interesting exhibits and corresponding background information. Professional leadership. Questions were also answered with pleasure and in detail. Highly recommended and again at any time. Thanks for the police story!

editorial_summary.overview: Live lectures & high-tech projections take visitors around the cosmos at this family attraction.

reviews.text:
Content good.
But very disappointed to see that all the seats are designed for Adults only. My daughter was not able to push back her seat, she is 9 years old. It was very uncomfortable to look up that she couldn’t concentrate . I recommend science dome in Heilbronn Experimenta instead

We visited here to watch the planetarium show. The seats are comfortable enough to watch the show with your friends and kids. However, kids might feel uncomfortable as it’s difficult for them to recline.

This is a really great venue with a variety of events and not just for star gazers. Check out the "Queen" show if you like Freddie and the boys music. It's a really great experience. Not lived in Stuttgart for a while but hopefully go back there and to this venue one day when we can travel 🤞

Reaching the entrance from the Main train station side is a bit difficult, especially with strollers or wheelchairs. The entrance was closed, even within working hours.
The hall, the movie and the overall experience were nice.
Very pleasant visit. Went to see the Queen show. It was nice, but I think I am use to 4K😅. But a nice we to spend an hour.

It is a great museum to visit with small kids who love tractors. We just visited the main faciltiy with 3 halls.

Really nice exhibition!

Great place...open Sundays.   Thank God someone is preserving these pieces of history.  3 big buildings of steam engines,  wood powered tractors, and vintage machinery.

Restore YouTubers should donate some time here making these functional!

Take your kids to show them what life was like before tv and internet
Pretty place. I didn't go in. Just took pics outside.
Awesome collection of ancient agricultural machines. Good for people studying agriculture or people who are farming. I wouldn't suggest this place for other people.
It was a pretty amazing view for the kids. Huge machines and a nice place to visit even on a rainy day 😊

editorial_summary.overview: Wine museum with historical artifacts, viticulture-related art & a gift shop offering samples.

reviews.text:
We walked the 2.2km up the hill from the train station, then back.

We went on a Sunday and there was only 3 other groups of people. It was nice to read about the wines, interesting big old building.

Afterwards asked about wines and sampling at the counter, we were given a menu, not much help, other people seemed to be getter an explanation of wines. It was not busy so could not interstate why the poor customer service.
Thanks for the service- it was good to know wine 🍷 making in Stuttgart

Simply love this small cosy museum! The hospitality was so great that I wanted to rate as much stars as I wanted too.

Thank you for the hospitality and the extra wine knowledge!

Very educational tour given by Mr Wolfgang Mack (probably the boss/owner, most likely a very experienced sommelier; I didn't ask). Overall great service, made us feel very welcome, like at a friend's house.

He recommended us a fruity white (Collegium Wirtemberg, 2015 Müller-Thurgau feinherb) which was wonderful - the first white wine I actually liked, and I don't even drink.

Interesting wine museum in Stuttgart that express the story and dewelopment of wineyards in BW. Its clear that wine quality not the best but good.  Inside is full of historical samples from the old days. I like the old wine openers. At the entrance you can taste some local wines. It would make a better marketing if they include the wine tasting in the ticket and increase little bit the entrance fee:)

Great guide with room for improvement on technical terms.

I recently had the pleasure of taking a guided tour of the VHS and overall I was very happy with the experience. The tour was well organized, informative and left me with a deeper understanding of computer museum.

The explanations during the tour were thorough and understandable. Mr. Klemens Krause were well prepared and were able to convey the knowledge in a clear and accessible way. The tour itself was structured and well planned, which contributed to a smooth process. I felt well taken care of throughout the experience.

However, there was one small point I would like to address. In my opinion, some technical terms were not explained in sufficient detail. Although most of the information was understandable, there were moments when I felt that a more detailed description of some technical terms would have been helpful. This could help people without extensive prior knowledge to fully understand what is being said.

Having said that, I would like to stress that the overall leadership was excellent. Mr. Klemens Krause was professional, well informed and able to answer any questions competently and comprehensively. He kept the group engaged and no one felt left out. The information provided was interesting and sparked my interest in learning more about the subject.

So overall the tour was great and informative. If the descriptions of the technical terms had been a bit more detailed, I would have rated the experience as perfect. Nonetheless, I highly recommend this tour

A small but fine computer museum. The exhibits are all still functional and Mr. Krause does a great job orchestrating all the equipment with ease. TOP location for IT nerds and everyone who wants to become one. :-)

Very nice little museum. Mr. Krause is a very competent lecturer and, on request, gave a guided tour of almost 120 minutes for the two of us with a precise description and demonstration. These are not the standard retro PCs, but really unique models that you don't know or have seen even with previous knowledge. The visit was very instructive for us and we are happy to recommend it to others.

definitely highly recommended. Extensive collection of mostly functional computers, from tube devices to examples of the development of hardware that is common today. Very good guidance by excellent experts. Highly recommended to any nerd or freak.
A really nice museum, with many intact ideas to try out, as well as a competent tour with a PowerPoint presentation and a lot of specialist knowledge. I can only recommend to everyone!
